Title: MultiModal-GPT: A Vision and Language Model for Dialogue with Humans
Authors: Tao Gong, Chengqi Lyu, Shilong Zhang, Yudong Wang, Miao Zheng, Qian Zhao, Kuikun Liu, Wenwei Zhang, Ping Luo, Kai Chen
Summary: We present a vision and language model named MultiModal-GPT to conduct multi-round dialogue with humans. MultiModal-GPT can follow various instructions from humans, such as generating a detailed caption, counting the number of interested objects, and answering general questions from users. MultiModal-GPT is parameter-efficiently fine-tuned from OpenFlamingo, with Low-rank Adapter (LoRA) added both in the cross-attention part and the self-attention part of the language model. We first construct instruction templates with vision and language data for multi-modality instruction tuning to make the model understand and follow human instructions. We find the quality of training data is vital for the dialogue performance, where few data containing short answers can lead the model to respond shortly to any instructions. To further enhance the ability to chat with humans of the MultiModal-GPT, we utilize language-only instruction-following data to train the MultiModal-GPT jointly. The joint training of language-only and visual-language instructions with the \emph{same} instruction template effectively improves dialogue performance. Various demos show the ability of continuous dialogue of MultiModal-GPT with humans. Code, dataset, and demo are at https://github.com/open-mmlab/Multimodal-GPT

main_contribution.headline: MultiModal-GPT: A Vision and Language Model for Human Dialogue
main_contribution.description: The paper introduces MultiModal-GPT, a vision and language model designed to conduct multi-round dialogue with humans. The model is fine-tuned from OpenFlamingo, with Low-rank Adapter (LoRA) incorporated in both the cross-attention and self-attention components of the language model. The authors construct instruction templates with vision and language data for multi-modality instruction tuning, enabling the model to comprehend and adhere to human directives. The paper emphasizes the importance of the quality of training data for effective dialogue performance. To enhance MultiModal-GPT’s conversational abilities, the authors employ language-only instruction-following data for joint training alongside visual-language instructions, resulting in a significant improvement in dialogue performance.

takeaways.headline: MultiModal-GPT Demonstrates Proficiency in Maintaining Continuous Dialogues with Humans
takeaways.description: The MultiModal-GPT model can be used to build systems that can engage in multi-round dialogues with humans, follow diverse instructions, generate detailed captions, count specific objects, and address general inquiries posed by users. The joint training of language-only instructions and visual and language instructions effectively improves the performance of the model. The model's proficiency in maintaining continuous dialogues with humans is demonstrated through various demos. The approach can be applied to build more interactive and user-friendly AI systems.
takeaways.example: For instance, in a customer service scenario, MultiModal-GPT can be used to interact with customers, understand their queries, and provide appropriate responses. It can also be used in educational settings to interact with students, understand their questions, and provide detailed explanations.

novelty_analysis: The paper presents a novel approach to fine-tuning a vision and language model for conducting multi-round dialogue with humans. The use of a unified instruction template for both language and visual instruction data during model training is a unique contribution. The authors also highlight the importance of the quality of training data for effective dialogue performance, which is a valuable insight.
technical_analysis: The paper is somewhat technical, discussing the architecture of the MultiModal-GPT model, the construction of instruction templates, and the joint training process. It also presents a detailed analysis of the impact of the quality of training data on the model's performance. However, the concepts are explained clearly, making the paper accessible to readers with a basic understanding of AI and machine learning.
enjoyable_analysis: The paper is well-structured and presents a clear narrative, making it an enjoyable read. The authors provide a detailed explanation of the model's architecture and training process, and the inclusion of various demos demonstrating the model's proficiency in maintaining continuous dialogues with humans adds to the paper's appeal.
